title: 南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队：用"土味"把党的创新理论唱进游客与村民心间
text:
2025年07月23日10:19 | 来源： 人民网 小字号
人民网漳州7月23日电 近日，上午的薄雾未散，在福建土楼（南靖）景区的情人桥畔，快板声、歌声已响起，7名身着红衣的姑娘正在排练《南靖土楼展新貌》《主题教育谱新篇》等节目。
在土楼前，南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队表演的《南靖土楼展新貌》，以通俗的唱词讲透惠民政策，优美的舞姿展现乡村新颜。南靖县融媒体中心供图
她们是当地小有名气的南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队。十余年来，这支平均年龄35岁的队伍用山歌、快板、情景剧等“土味”文艺形式，把党的创新理论融入青山绿水，唱进游客与村民心间，成为景区里一道跃动的红色风景线。
南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队成立于2012年，最初由当地土楼妹子自发组建，如今已发展为8人的专业宣讲队。南靖县从景区导游中选拔能歌善舞、能说会道的骨干充实队伍。景区讲解员伊林英回忆：“刚加入时怕讲不好，老队员就在夜里开小灶，一句一句打磨歌词、吃透政策。”
目前，队员身份多元，有每日接待游客的讲解员，有打理茶园的茶农，有经营民宿的个体户，还有熟悉村务的村主干。不同的职业背景，让她们更懂基层群众与游客的需求。
“零距离”“无缝隙”是南靖土楼红妹子的标签。她们的戏台从景区广场搬到村口晒谷场、农家小院。在和贵楼前，《南靖土楼展新貌》的表演常能瞬间聚拢人群：清脆的快板打出发展节奏，通俗的唱词讲透惠民政策，优美的舞姿展现乡村新颜。游客们举着手机录像，孩子们跟着节奏拍手，掌声与笑声在土楼间回荡。
褪去舞台灯光，南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队又钻进村民小店。她们用地道闽南话演起反诈小品，赢得小店老板许阿姨直点头：“我很喜欢土楼红妹子这种入户宣讲方式，让我们在家门口就能够了解党的政策。”
截至目前，南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队累计演出500余场，吸引20余万人次观看，创作节目20余个，涵盖国家安全、反诈、乡村振兴等主题。表演视频《土楼人民笑开颜》获省级优秀理论宣讲微视频，团队获评福建省三八红旗集体。
“南靖土楼红妹子宣讲队通过‘理论+文艺+互动’的形式，让党的声音传遍土楼每个角落。如今，该宣讲队已成为南靖土楼的文化名片。”南靖县土楼管委会主任陈艺君说。（苏海森 陈雪滨 阮钿元 陈宇轩）
(责编：江苇杭、刘卿) 分享让更多人看到

title: Women shine a light in their communities amid conflict and climate shocks
text:
Women shine a light in their communities amid conflict and climate shocks
By Basma Ourfali
Women are among the hardest hit in emergencies, but they are also among the first responders. From Burundi to Zambia, women champions in Southern and Eastern Africa are stepping up to support women and girls but also their entire community, aiming to change the narrative of gender inequality and improve people’s lives.
In the spirit of International Women’s Day, we share some of their stories
Ekenia, Zimbabwe
Ekenia Chifamba is a girls’ rights activist and the founder and director of Shamwari Yemwanasikana (Friend of the Girl Child), a non-governmental organization (NGO) in Zimbabwe that promotes rights and empowers girls. It operates in Harare, Manicaland, Mashonaland Central, Mashonaland East and Masvingo Provinces.
Ekenia grew up in Chitungwiza, some 25 km from the capital, Harare, where violations of women’s and girls’ rights was rampant. She attended university, as her family valued equal education and empowerment opportunities for boys and girls.
“I grew up seeing women and girls in my community face numerous challenges, including gender-based violence (GBV), and limited access to education, health care and job opportunities,” she explained. “This is due to poverty, restricted opportunities for girls in remote rural areas, social norms, and lack of awareness of the needs and rights of these girls and women.”
Ekenia decided to help change the fortunes of these girls. Through her NGO, she established safe centres for survivors of abuse. The centres offer GBV and health services, catch-up classes and training in livelihood skills, including baking, poultry production, making reusable sanitary pads, carpentry, market gardening and sewing.
“Since 2014, we have supported more than 15,000 girls through our girls support and protection services programme, and provided entrepreneurship training to 1,500 women and girls,” said Ekenia. “My hope is to see more girls fully empowered and developed to actively participate in civic and political spaces.”
Fatima, Somalia
Fatima, 25, lives in Mogadishu, Somalia. She works with the Northern Frontier Youth League, focusing on education, fighting GBV and enhancing health-care services to support vulnerable people.
"Many of the GBV cases we received come from displacement camps, with rape being the most common,” she explained. “Women in these settings face various challenges, including limited access to health-care services, which exacerbates their vulnerability.
"I saw how violence against women, including intimate-partner violence, child marriage, rape and female genital mutilation, cause lifelong suffering.”
Fatima and her team provide counselling and psychosocial support to survivors of different types of abuse, with support from the Somalia Humanitarian Fund.
But the road has not been easy; Fatima’s campaigns have been met with resistance, even from her own family. Despite numerous threats and negative rumours, she remains resolute in her mission:
"What motivates me to keep fighting and assisting women and girls in the community, despite the challenges, is that they look up to me.”
Fatima’s dedication to fight GBV in Somalia prompted her to write a book on the issue. Hadimo Haween (Problems Women Face), published in 2022, covers incidents that she documented between 2016 and 2021, including first-hand stories from survivors about the impact of GBV, especially female genital mutilation, on their lives.
Chancelle, Burundi
When Chancelle Bamuhaye was 16, she participated in UNICEF Burundi’s Young Journalist Programme. The experience enabled her to work with vulnerable children, understand their problems and needs, and consequently challenge herself as to what she could do to ensure positive changes in their lives.
Now 27, Chancelle is the founder and director of Hope for a Better Future, an NGO that provides education, health and nutrition support to children.
She explained:
"Since establishing the NGO in 2019, we have grown from supporting 46 children to over 1,000. We provide stationery supplies, school uniforms, shoes, clothes, school meals and desks to schools where children sit on the floor. We particularly focus on the Batwa Indigenous group and albino children, who are among the most vulnerable communities in Burundi. Our aim is to empower them to become self-reliant and contribute to the development of their communities when they grow up.”
Ireen, Zambia
More than half of the women in
Africa live in rural areas. These women significantly contribute to Africa’s agriculture, and they fuel local and global economies. But they also face disadvantages in access, control of resources regarding land and livestock ownership, decision-making and access to financing.
Ireen Chikatula is the founder and director of the Empowerment Initiative for Rural Women and Adolescents (EIRWA). She lives and works in Rufunsa, a district on the outskirts of Zambia’s capital, Lusaka. Despite being close to the capital, Rufunsa remains marginalized and its population of more than 80,000 people lack empowerment.
“Back in 2016, I was working as a nurse in a rural health centre in Rufunsa. It was eye opening,” said Ireen. “I received many women with scars on their bodies because of abuse and violence. I met girls who couldn't attend school because they didn’t have shoes. When I attempted to connect them with appropriate support groups or services, I discovered that such services were not available in my community. At that moment, I knew I had to take action.”
Ireen founded EIRWA in 2020 to provide literacy classes, entrepreneurial skills, health care and reproductive awareness, as adolescent pregnancies affect many girls in her community.
She added:
“In rural Zambia, some cultural practices encourage women to stay at home, making them dependent. While I respect the importance of culture and traditions, I firmly believe that any practices that perpetuate harm or discrimination must be challenged and dismantled.”
So far, EIRWA has supported hundreds of women with training in life skills, beekeeping, entrepreneurship and agricultural activities.
“What impresses me most is seeing the progress in the women we trained,” said Ireen. “I’ve seen many of them learn to express themselves, make informed decisions and pursue their education, and even start their own small businesses.”
Tamanda, Malawi
Tropical Cyclone Freddy tore through southern Malawi in 2023, hitting 15 districts in the southern region. It killed hundreds of people, displaced more than half a million and destroyed more than 20,000 hectares of crops. Entire communities were cut off from essential services, including food and health care.
Tamanda Mzima, a general medical practitioner in Malawi’s Blantyre District, rushed to help, volunteering at the Manja site for displaced people.
"I cover the night shifts, as most medical doctors prefer to work during the daytime," she said.
Tamanda and other health-care workers also distribute health information and chlorine to mitigate the spread of communicable diseases.
"The majority of people I assist here are women, who bear the brunt of emergencies such as floods,” said Tamanda.
“They primarily experience problems such as diarrhoea, malaria and upper respiratory issues. This is due to overcrowding at some camps and the inadequate availability of drinking water and sanitation facilities."
Women and children are 14 times more likely than men to die during natural disasters and crises. This is due to gender-specific barriers and inequalities that affect people’s exposure, vulnerability, preparedness and coping mechanisms.
Ranja, Madagascar
In Madagascar, the situation for many women remains dire. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, cyclones and inflation, the humanitarian crisis in the country’s South-East region has significantly deteriorated. There is a severe lack of access to basic necessities such as food, health care and security. Single women and female-headed families are especially vulnerable, as traditional norms prevent them from inheriting family property, such as land, houses and plantations. Moreover, opportunities for employment and other sources of income are becoming increasingly scarce.
Ranjatiana Randriantsara (Ranja), a university professor in anthropology, joined the Fanavotana Association to support affected women and girls in the South-East region.
Ranja explained: “Following successive devastating cyclones, many women lost their source of income, particularly in farming, as everything was destroyed by Cyclones Batsiray and Emnati in 2022, followed by Cyclone Freddy in 2023. These women have become extremely vulnerable and had to accept any available job opportunity, often experiencing abuse and sexual exploitation at work and within their communities.”
Ranja and her team provide psychosocial support and counselling, and they reintegrate the women’s children into schools and supply essential aid. They also refer them to courses that help improve their livelihood skills.
“Seeing these women get back on their feet to live again with dignity is my greatest satisfaction,” Ranja said.
Mama Maincha, Mozambique
Mama Maincha Pitara, now 70, started the Legal Office Organization in Pemba, the capital of northern Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado Province, in 1992. She offers free counselling, protection and legal services to people who can’t afford them.
Her inspiration to start the organization was the numerous challenges facing women and girls in Cabo Delgado. Many cannot attend school or access quality health care because of poverty. Women also lack opportunities for income-generating activities, which leaves them vulnerable to violence and sexual exploitation.
In October 2017, violence erupted in Cabo Delgado, displacing more than 1 million people, and exacerbating poverty and deprivation.
Mama Maincha explained:
“Since the conflict began, we've seen a rise in GBV cases. Many couples have lost their livelihoods or been displaced. They have to provide for their children and start from scratch. This has led to increased tension at home and instances of domestic violence.”
Mama Maincha and her team also help these families find jobs and accommodation, and access health services. They provide advice and referral pathways to those experiencing domestic and GBV problems, and they channel cases to state institutes and refer those who require legal consultation to an organization to fund the expenses.
Through mobile teams, the Legal Office Organization provides services in all 17 districts of Cabo Delgado Province. However, funding challenges prevent them from accessing some districts.
Rumbi, Mozambique
Another advocate in Mozambique is 26-year-old Rumbidzai Dhliwayo (Rumbi), based in Pemba. For the past two years, she has served communities across Cabo Delgado, Nampula and Niassa Provinces through the local NGO Girl Child Rights, which supports girls and women, including those with disabilities.
Rumbi explained:
"Most women look down on themselves; they don’t know their rights or their worth, largely due to societal teachings. We live in a society where the boy child is favoured as the family heir, receiving prioritized access to educational and financial opportunities.”
Despite the unstable conditions in Cabo Delgado, Rumbi and her team have reached thousands of women, providing essential health and psychosocial support services, safe spaces and economic activities in agriculture, poultry farming and fish selling.
But Rumbi encounters challenges, as not everyone accepts women who try to make a difference. Nevertheless, she and her team continue to find solutions to overcome these obstacles.
"We have been collaborating with community and religious leaders to promote transformative behaviour among men," she explains. "This initiative has had a significant impact in some communities, where we have successfully identified male role models, or Male Champions, who help disseminate messages against GBV and raise awareness of its negative consequences."
To build inclusive and prosperous societies, it’s essential to invest in women-led organizations and woman humanitarians, fund projects that assist women in emergencies, and support feminist change makers.

author: Justice Nwafor
title: Electric Vehicles and Tax Incentives: A Win-Win for Colorado Residents
text:
In the heart of the Rocky Mountains, a revolution is quietly unfolding, promising not only to reshape the transportation landscape of Colorado but also to bolster the financial health of its residents. As electric vehicles (EVs) gain traction on the roads, they bring with them a promise of thousands of dollars in lifetime cost savings for Colorado consumers, juxtaposed against the backdrop of a statewide initiative to encourage tax filing for maximizing returns. This narrative explores the economic and environmental tapestry of Colorado's shift towards cleaner vehicles and the synergistic impact of tax incentives on societal well-being.
The Electric Shift: A Financial and Environmental Win
The transition to electric vehicles in Colorado is not just a step towards reducing carbon footprints but also a leap towards substantial financial savings for vehicle owners. With the cost of gasoline vehicles continuously on the rise, EVs offer a more economical and sustainable alternative. The savings narrative extends beyond the point of purchase, with electric vehicles offering reduced maintenance and operational costs over their lifetime. Colorado fortifies this transition with generous tax credits, including federal tax credits up to $7,500 and state tax credits up to $5,000 for all EVs, with an additional $2,500 for those priced under $35,000. The Inflation Reduction Act further mandates that to qualify for these new vehicle consumer tax credits, EVs must be assembled in North America, a move that promises to galvanize the electric vehicle manufacturing sector in the region.
Maximizing Returns: Colorado's Tax Incentive Program
In a parallel move aimed at enhancing the financial well-being of its residents, the Colorado Department of Health has announced the continuation of a statewide program that encourages Coloradans to file their taxes and maximize their returns. Despite the availability of significant returns through tax credits, it is estimated that one in four eligible individuals fail to claim the Colorado Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). The program targets new parents, non-English speakers, individuals without access to free tax help, and those who mistakenly believe they are ineligible because they do not owe income tax. The potential financial uplift from these tax credits is substantial, with eligible Coloradans receiving up to $800 individually or $1,600 for joint filers through the Taxpayer's Bill of Rights (TABOR) refund, and families could see up to $2,000 per child through the Colorado EITC.
A Synergistic Impact: Health, Education, and Financial Well-being
The benefits of Colorado's twin initiatives extend far beyond immediate financial savings and environmental stewardship. Studies have linked the availability of tax credits like the EITC to significant societal benefits, including reduced infant mortality, lower instances of low birth weight, increased intergenerational health, and improvements in educational attainment and earnings. By encouraging the adoption of electric vehicles and maximizing tax return benefits through state and federal credits, Colorado is not only fostering a healthier environment but is also laying down the foundation for improved societal health and economic stability for its residents.
As Colorado navigates this transformative era, the convergence of economic incentives for electric vehicle purchase and the push for maximizing tax returns represents a holistic approach to addressing climate change, economic disparity, and societal well-being. Through strategic investments in cleaner transportation options and by ensuring that financial benefits reach those most in need, Colorado is setting a precedent for how states can harness policy to drive positive change. This narrative of progress, underscored by the dual thrust of environmental sustainability and economic empowerment, captures the essence of Colorado's efforts to pave a greener, more prosperous future for its residents.

author: Brigid Kennedy Sports Illustrated
title: Scottie Scheffler Bravely Includes Ravioli on Masters Dinner Menu Despite Hand Injury
text:
Sports
Scottie Scheffler Bravely Includes Ravioli on Masters Dinner Menu Despite Hand Injury
As is customary for the defending champion, 2024 Masters winner Scottie Scheffler has compiled a
delicious-looking menu for the 2025 Masters dinner-and he included one dish that might make avid Scheffler heads chuckle.
Among the menu's many tasty bites, which include some of the same dishes from when he hosted the meal in 2023 (firecracker shrimp, cheeseburger sliders, and a chocolate chip cookie skillet, for example), Scheffler added three new foods to the mix: Texas-style chili, "Papa Scheff's" meatballs, and, quite fittingly, ravioli bites.
Intentionally or not, the ravioli bites serve as a callback to the
hand injury Scheffler suffered over the holidays last year; the two-time Masters champ cut his hand cooking ravioli for Christmas dinner and needed surgery to remove some of the glass.
Thankfully, Scheffler won't be in the kitchen in Augusta on April 8, so the only hazard he'll have to watch out for is stains on his outfit.
Take a peek at the full menu, which also features the return of the ribeye steak and blackened redfish, below:
Served in honor of Mr. Scottie Scheffler.- The Masters (@TheMasters)
[#themasters] [pic.twitter.com/24VayDZhgs] [March 19, 2025]
The 2025 Masters Tournament will run from April 10 to April 13 at Augusta National Golf Course. After playing host, Scheffler will, of course, be competing in the tourney for his third green jacket.

title: Gobierno nacional estudia declarar día cívico si Selección Colombia gana la Copa América - BluRadio
text: El lunes 15 de julio podría ser declarado día cívico por el Gobierno nacional si la [Selección Colombia](https://www.bluradio.com/regiones/caribe/se-lo-merecen-amigos-y-familiares-de-jugadores-costenos-de-la-seleccion-colombia-rg10) gana su segundo título de la [Copa América.](https://www.bluradio.com/deportes/futbol/copa-america/este-es-el-equipo-ideal-de-la-semifinal-de-la-copa-america-no-aparece-james-so35) El ejecutivo evalúa expedir un decreto que cobije a funcionarios y entidades del orden nacional, dejando a discreción de gobernadores y alcaldes acatar esta medida. Luego de la histórica semifinal en la que se derrotó 1-0 a [Uruguay,](https://www.bluradio.com/deportes/futbol/copa-america/jugador-uruguayo-lanzo-objeto-a-tribuna-y-le-corto-la-frente-a-asistente-de-bielsa-so35) con gol de [Jefferson Lerma,](https://www.bluradio.com/deportes/futbol/copa-america/gol-de-jefferson-lerma-el-heroe-colombiano-que-pone-a-sonar-a-todo-un-pais-so35) varios gobernadores y alcaldes manifestaron en redes sociales que aplicarían la medida en caso de ser campeones. Algunos de los mandatario locales que han expresado la intención de aplicar esa medida son gobernador de Bolívar, Yamil Arana; el gobernador de Norte de Santander, William Villamizar; la gobernadora del Tolima, Adriana Magali, y el alcalde de Santa Rosa de Cabal, Paulo Gómez. title: Estas son las mejores combinaciones de jeans negros con suéteres calientitos para el frío
text:
¿Existe algo mÃ¡s versÃ¡til que los vaqueros tradicionales? SÃ­, los jeans negros. No solo combinan con todo (absolutamente todo), sino que favorecen la silueta, crean el efecto de unas piernas más alargadas y, lo más importante, son el comodín de estilo para llevar suéteres calientitos. Especialmente en enero, ya que es uno de los meses más fríos del año, sin embargo, eso no quiere decir que pierdas el estilo o lleves prendas que no encajen con tu personalidad. La idea es aprovechar la variedad de diseños y divertirte con las piezas de lana, afelpadas o con motivos de rayas igual de acogedoras que tu manta favorita.
De acuerdo al reporte de moda del 2024, los texanos en color negro son un clásico indispensable que no puede faltar en tu colección. Balenciaga, Phillip Lim, Celine y Dolce & Gabbana son solo algunas de las firmas que los incluyeron en pasarelas de Primavera-Verano 2024, por lo tanto, no será extraño verlos opacar a los jeans blancos de siempre. Lo cierto es que no basta con tener un modelo en particular, la idea es aprovechar las diferentes siluetas que hay para ti, desde baggy jeans hasta skinny o de tiro alto, estos serán el secreto para definir mucho mejor tu estilo de la manera más práctica posible.
Estas son las mejores combinaciones de jeans negros con suéteres calientitos para el frío
Cómo llevar faldas con suéteres en Primavera-Verano 2024, una tendencia irresistible
Una combinación algo controversial, que, sin embargo, se posiciona como unas de las más prácticas y elegantes. Solo recuerda llevarla correctamente así…
Por suerte, no tendrás que preocuparte por crear estilismos acertados. Enlistamos los siete looks que serán tu guía para verte maravillosa de pies a cabeza, conoce cuáles son las opciones que hay para ti y, de paso, descubre dónde conseguir diseños similares.
¿Cómo combinar jeans negros con suéteres calientitos en enero 2024? Jeans negros acampanados con suéter blanco acanalado
Un suéter sencillo es lo único que requieres para verte distintiva y atractiva en enero 2024.
Como ya lo hemos mencionado anteriormente, la lista de jeans en tendencia de Primavera-Verano 2024 trae nuevas sorpresas para la temporada. Entre ellas, los diseños acampanados en color negro de estética boho, perfectos para darle un poco de alegría al atuendo sin enfundarte en varias capas. Siempre serán los protagonistas del look, por lo tanto, no tendrás que esforzarte demasiado en elevar el resultado, un suéter blanco acanalado, junto con zapatos normcore serán más que suficientes para verte divina al instante. Finaliza con un cinturón y accesorios discretos.
Suéter de Arket.
Marni.
Baggy jeans con suéter gris de lana
¡No lo subestimes! Un suÃ©ter gris es la clave para darle un toque sofisticado y cool a tu estilo.
En lugar de llevar baggy jeans negros con camisetas blancas (como normalmente lo harías), mejor opta por un suéter clásico. Puede que pienses que las piezas de lana en color gris son aburridas o muy serias, sin embargo, las que más saben de moda demuestran que también se pueden llevar en clave moderna. ¿Cómo? Por debajo de chaquetas biker, de este modo aportas una nota sofisticada al atuendo sin acudir a lo predecible. Complementa con tenis Adidas Samba y estarás lista para conquistar las calles de la ciudad con un estilo ganador.
Suéter de Uniqlo.
Bggy jeans negros de Ksubi.
Mom jeans con suéter verde de cuello alto
Añade un acento de color al look a través de un suéter calientito en verde trébol que no pase por alto.
Si te encantan los estilismos con acentos de color, entonces, tendrás que tener uno o varios pares de pantalones de mezclilla negros, pues serán la base principal del atuendo. Y, nada mejor que unos mom jeans oscuros que favorecen la silueta, sigue el consejo de estilo y combínalos con suéteres de cuello alto en verde trébol, junto con botines metalizados. Un dúo poderoso y calientito para no pasar desapercibida en los días más fríos del mes de enero.
Ralph Lauren.
Citizens of Humanity.
Jeans ceñidos con campana y suéter rosa de peluche
Jeans negros con suéteres de peluche, la pareja perfecta para evocar un estilo minimalista y relajado.
¡No lo guardes! Aquel suéter afelpado que recibiste en el intercambio navideño o que compraste de emergencia en el otoño es la llave para crear atuendos minimalistas que encajan en cualquier contexto. La idea es enlazarlos con tus jeans negros favoritos (pueden ser acampanados), añade zuecos o zapatos normcore a tono con los vaqueros ¡y listo! Algo casual, pero atractivo que te salvará del típico ‘qué me pongo’ para la rutina matutina.
Pinko.
Diesel.
Skinny jeans negros con suéter de rayas de cuello alto
Los suertes de rayas son los más bonitos de la temporada y quedan divinos con skinny jeans negros.
ANINE BING.
Skinny jeans negros de Levi’s.
Baggy jeans negros con suéter tejido
Suéter calientito con baggy jeans negros, la dupla infalible para enfrentar el frío de enero con estilo.
Otra de las mil formas de llevar texanos anchos en color negro con alta dosis de estilo es al enlazarlos con suéteres tejidos en color beige. Esta vez, los texanos irán por dentro de las botas altas, no importa si no son ceñidos, el secreto está en ornamentar la figura y crear un efecto relajado en el look. Complementa con un chaleco con forro de lana y prepárate para recibir cumplidos del día a la noche.
Chanel.
Jeans de tiro alto de Pinko.
Slim jeans negros con suéter canalé en color café
Un suéter acanalado en color café siempre es una excelente opción para ir bien vestida con vaqueros.
Ya sea para la oficina, universidad o simplemente para sumarte a la tendencia, no dudes en inclinarte por slim jeans negros y suéteres cálidos que te proteja de las bajas temperaturas. ¿Necesitas inspiración? Un diseño acanalado en color café y con cuello de tortuga será la prenda estelar para ir bien vestida de manera natural y sin planearlo demasiado. Culmina con unas botas de combate con costuras a la vista para aportar el toque cool que marcará la diferencia, una propuesta que ya hemos visto en celebridades como Selena Gomez y Dua Lipa.
Cos.
